entry.title: New SRAM Rival AXS Brake Levers
entry.summary: A package with two SRAM Rival boxes was dropped off at offtrail.guru headquarters. Here's the scoop. The SRAM Red AXS hoods that were initially on my Nordest Albarda were transferred to my Ritte Snob Disc, from which I stole them to build my 2025 Marin Gestalt X12G. They will be going back to the Ritte at the end of the year. New 2025 SRAM Force AXS hoods are going to take their place. To keep the X12B and X12G similar, I decided to replace the 2-year-old Rival hoods (model ID ED-RIV-D1) with brand-spanking-new brake levers (model ID ED-RIV-E1).
entry.content:
A package with two SRAM Rival boxes was dropped off at offtrail.guru headquarters. Here's the scoop. The SRAM Red AXS hoods that were initially on my Nordest Albarda were transferred to my Ritte Snob Disc, from which I stole them to build my 2025 Marin Gestalt X12G. They will be going back to the Ritte at the end of the year. New 2025 SRAM Force AXS hoods are going to take their place. To keep the X12B and X12G similar, I decided to replace the 2-year-old Rival hoods (model ID ED-RIV-D1) with brand-spanking-new brake levers (model ID ED-RIV-E1).

The new design isn't a rebadged version of what came before. The all-new hoods are longer and slimmer. There's enough room to wrap all four fingers and the thumb around the hood. SRAM claims it provides a better grip, resulting in less hand fatigue. The biggest improvement comes from the redesigned brake levers. SRAM claims 80% less effort when braking from hoods, and 33% less effort when braking from the drops. The new levers have a higher pivot point that's farther forward. SRAM switched to a "push piston" design, similar to how mountain bike brakes work. This simplifies the internals, provides a more direct hose installation without requiring a second wrench, and reduces a significant amount of weight.

They're definitely a step forward. I like the shape and feel. To differentiate the old Rival levers from Force and Red, SRAM used LFRT (long-fiber-reinforced thermoplastic) brake levers. They had a stealth matte and gloss-black finish. The new ones are a step up and come with carbon brake levers like their higher-end Force and Red siblings. You get bonus buttons that provide an auxiliary shift option or ANT+ device control with Force and Red. I don't use any devices on my bike, but additional thumb-shifters would be handy. The more affordable Rival levers forgo that extra feature. The grey "Rival" logotype matches the grey of the rear derailleur — a thumbs-up for that.

I purchased the levers together with the calipers, which I'm not using. They're said to be stiffer. They're noticeably lighter and cool-looking. I'll be doing the same with my X12G at the end of the year, but on this bike, the calipers will be used. The installation was done in three days:

  • Day 1 to take off the old levers and install the new ones
  • Day 2 to wrap the bars
  • Day 3 to bleed the brakes

That's just how I like to get things done — no need to do it all at once in one marathon session.

entry.title: 2023 Vs. 2025 Marin Gestalt X10
entry.summary: Besides the obvious color change, the 2025 Marin Gestalt X10 has undergone slight changes from the 2023 model. The microSHIFT Advent X groupset was replaced by Sword, and the blackwall Vee Tire Rocket Man tires were swapped with skinwall 700Cx45 Quickstyx tires. Since I only used frame, fork, headset, and thru-axles, let's take a look at what changed between 2023 and 2025. The biggest change is the fork. It's an entirely new fork. It is beefier, and the fork legs have a more triangular shape. The thread in the fork crown to attach a fender moved from the front to the underside of the crown. The steerer tube of the 2023 fork had a 45° shoulder and doesn't require a race, while the 2025 fork uses one. Personally, I prefer the more rounded shape of the old fork.
entry.content:
Besides the obvious color change, the 2025 Marin Gestalt X10 has undergone slight changes from the 2023 model. The microSHIFT Advent X groupset was replaced by Sword, and the blackwall Vee Tire Rocket Man tires were swapped with skinwall 700Cx45 Quickstyx tires. Since I only used frame, fork, headset, and thru-axles, let's take a look at what changed between 2023 and 2025. The biggest change is the fork. It's an entirely new fork. It is beefier, and the fork legs have a more triangular shape. The thread in the fork crown to attach a fender moved from the front to the underside of the crown. The steerer tube of the 2023 fork had a 45° shoulder and doesn't require a race, while the 2025 fork uses one. Personally, I prefer the more rounded shape of the old fork.

The 2023 frame has massive tire clearance. As a result, chainring clearance is tight. Marin gave the 2025 frame slightly more chainring clearance. As a result, tire clearance had to be reduced a bit. The 55 mm wide René Herse Antelope Hill tires still fit, though. It would have been neat to future-proof the frame with a UDH dropout, but I can live with that. I will be running 1x12 drivetrains for the next couple of years.

Well, that's everything already. It was an excellent bike when it was released, so not much needed to be changed. The increased chainring clearance offers people more options with chainring sizes or chainline. I was happy with the chainstays of the 2023 model. At the end of the year, I'll replace the SRAM Red brakes with the new Force brakes. Not because the bike needs them, but because I'd like to move the brake levers back to my Ritte Snob Disc, from which I stole them for the X12G.

entry.title: Marin Gestalt X12G
entry.summary: When you read a press release about a new road or gravel bike, do they ever talk about geometry? Hardly ever. The latest and greatest road bike is promoted as faster, stiffer, and more aerodynamic than its predecessor. Most marketing is race-focused and speed-obsessed. Claimed reductions in aerodynamic drag and the watts saved, as a result, are things that a weekend warrior like myself cannot verify and will not notice while riding. When companies issue such press releases to online bike publications, I greet them with a massive yawn. The bike industry is turning wrong by focusing on race-only bikes for World Tour and domestic professionals, ignoring that most cyclists don't race.
entry.content:
When you read a press release about a new road or gravel bike, do they ever talk about geometry? Hardly ever. The latest and greatest road bike is promoted as faster, stiffer, and more aerodynamic than its predecessor. Most marketing is race-focused and speed-obsessed. Claimed reductions in aerodynamic drag and the watts saved, as a result, are things that a weekend warrior like myself cannot verify and will not notice while riding. When companies issue such press releases to online bike publications, I greet them with a massive yawn. The bike industry is turning wrong by focusing on race-only bikes for World Tour and domestic professionals, ignoring that most cyclists don't race.

Gravel bikes, in particular, serve as "do-it-all" bikes for most. Yet somehow, the bikes on which Pogačar wins the Tour and van der Poel wins the Gravel WC should be the bikes I want to ride. Tell you what, a 56-year-old dude with a 7-to-5 job can't do anything worse for his health and enjoyment than riding a bike built for a 26-year-old professional athlete. Strangely, many seem to think what's good for a pro is good for them. The aerodynamic advantages that save Pogačar a handful of seconds up the Mont Ventoux are meaningless for Joe Average. What truly matters is how a bike feels and how it handles. It's utterly unimportant if I can ride a particular loop 0.05 km/h faster. What matters, however, is how I feel when I get home. Am I beaten up because the frame is too stiff, or do I come back with a smile because the frame is designed for comfort?

While steel is hailed for its vibration-eating comfort and carbon is praised for its race-winning stiffness, tube shapes, diameters, and wall thicknesses are just as important as the material of a frame. Above all is how the single tubes that make up a bike frame are sized to form the geometry of a frame. Whereas mountain bikers chew over stack and reach, head and seat tube angles, or fork offset and trail, it seems to me that such things don't seem to garner a lot of interest in road or gravel circles. It should, though. Bike geometry defines how the rider sits on the bike, where the center of gravity of the rider and bike are, and how the unit of the two will behave while moving. Geometry defines how a bike handles uphill and downhill, how it turns or copes with crosswinds, how stable it rolls on the flat, and how easily it sprints.

I bought a Gestalt X10 in the spring of 2023 and made my X12B out of it. Other than Evil's Chamois Hagar, no road/all-road/gravel bikes are on the market with such a "progressive" geometry. I've already put 6,188.0 km on my X12B. To ensure thousands more miles on this excellent platform, the X12G was born. It shares a lot of the same parts as the X12B, with a few notable differences. It shifts with a SRAM Red derailleur instead of Rival. The saddle and seatpost differ. While the X12B is equipped with René Herse Antelope Hill 700C x 55mm tires, the new X12G has narrower 48mm Hatcher Pass tires.

entry.title: Possibly My Last Bike Purchase
entry.summary: I recently bought a second Marin Gestalt X10 to build my X12G. The X12G is very similar to my 2023 X12B. I set it up with several on-hand parts, both used and new, and a bunch of newly purchased ones, just like I always do. I turn 56 this year, and the Gestalt X12G is possibly the last bike I built. I have a fleet of seven complete bikes and an incomplete road bike, the Ritte Snob Disc. There's a fat-bike, a single-speed, and a 27.5+ geared MTB for trail riding. Then, there are four drop-bar bikes for road and gravel. All of them can be ridden for several more years. If I rebuild the Ritte Snob Disc and ride each of my drop-bar bikes for 3 years, that's 15 years. I'll be 71 years old.
entry.content:
I recently bought a second Marin Gestalt X10 to build my X12G. The X12G is very similar to my 2023 X12B. I set it up with several on-hand parts, both used and new, and a bunch of newly purchased ones, just like I always do. I turn 56 this year, and the Gestalt X12G is possibly the last bike I built. I have a fleet of seven complete bikes and an incomplete road bike, the Ritte Snob Disc. There's a fat-bike, a single-speed, and a 27.5+ geared MTB for trail riding. Then, there are four drop-bar bikes for road and gravel. All of them can be ridden for several more years. If I rebuild the Ritte Snob Disc and ride each of my drop-bar bikes for 3 years, that's 15 years. I'll be 71 years old.

Since winters are getting shorter and snow is getting rarer, my 44 Snakedriver fat-bike should be with me for years. My 44 Marauder single-speed has 3,700 kilometers. Thanks to sliding dropouts, it could be turned into a geared 29er if I ever wanted to. The Stooge MK5 can also be ridden for many more years. At present, it only has 2,250 kilometers on the odometer. I can easily put another 20,000 kilometers on all three combined. That will take a while.

The X12B and X12G will share road and gravel duties. The older X12B will be ridden from fall to spring, while the newer X12G will be used from spring to fall. The Nordest Albarda and Volagi Viaje, which I completely rebuilt, will return to action after the two Marins reach the end of their service lives. Both have more traditional geometries that allow bike fit changes that may be necessary as I age. A lot can be done on those two bikes with reduced saddle setbacks or shorter and taller stems.

I rebuilt my Ritte Snob Disc in April 2024, only to take it apart a year later. It's without brake/shift levers, derailleurs, and cranks. I may reassemble it at the end of the year or next, though I'm not yet sure how. If I go 2x12, I have cassettes and chainrings lying around. If I opt for 1x12, I would need a few more things. Either way, I will likely opt for SRAM Force AXS, the yet unreleased 2x12 groupset, or the current 1x12 XPLR edition. Orange Raketa cranks would be my preference for a 1x12 setup, and Rotor Aldhu carbon cranks in the case of 2x12.

So, while my Marin Gestalt X12G may be the last bike I built, I won't be done wrenching any time soon. It's nice to think that the fleet I have is the fleet I'll be riding into old age. Whenever cycling news sites reprint manufacturer's press releases, I can skip them all. With a basement full of bicycles, the future is well provided for. N+1 is all but history. Stay tuned for an introduction to the X12G, maybe a post about the differences between the 2023 and 2025 Gestalt X, and a future post about my return to tubes, albeit modern-day TPU tubes.

entry.title: My Favorite Road Tires
entry.summary: In the old days, road cyclists firmly believed that tires needed to be narrow and inflated to ridiculous pressures to be fast. 25 mm wide tires used to be the de facto standard. In more recent times, many warmed up to 28 mm tires. While René Herse has been testing and comparing much wider tires for many years, bike publications have only very recently discovered that wide tires don't slow you down. Cyclingnews now says that "40mm road tires are faster for nearly everyone".
entry.content:
In the old days, road cyclists firmly believed that tires needed to be narrow and inflated to ridiculous pressures to be fast. 25 mm wide tires used to be the de facto standard. In more recent times, many warmed up to 28 mm tires. While René Herse has been testing and comparing much wider tires for many years, bike publications have only very recently discovered that wide tires don't slow you down. Cyclingnews now says that "40mm road tires are faster for nearly everyone".

I didn't have to wait for them to tell me something I'd known for almost a decade. I set up my red Volagi Viaje road bike with Compass Barlow Pass tires in 2016 and never looked back. Since then, I've ridden almost every tire width between 38 and 55 mm in 650B and 700C. Ironically, the largest of them are also the ones I like most. In 650B, that's the 48 mm (52mm on my rims) Panaracer Gravelking slick tires. In 700C, René Herse's 55 mm wide Antelope Hill tires are my all-time favorites.

We cyclists hate when something slows us down. A narrow tire that wasn't adequately inflated or lost air or a brake that was rubbing, we quickly complained when our bike was holding us back. I never felt that way when using ever wider tires. While I don't have the data to say that a tire made me faster or slower, I can definitively say that wider tires add comfort. The fresher I stay on the bike, the longer I can ride and the easier I can get back on the bike the next day.

The road tires I've purchased since 2016:
Size Brand Model Weight Bike Year
700C x 38 Compass Barlow Pass 385 g Volagi Viaje 2016
650B x 47 WTB Horizon 515 g Volagi Viaje 2018
650B x 42 Compass Babyshoe Pass 415 g not yet used 2021
650B x 48 Compass Switchback Hill 460 g Nordest Albarda 2021
700C x 42 Teravail Washburn 520 g Nordest Albarda 2021
700C x 44 René Herse Snoqualmie Pass 380 g Nordest Albarda 2021
650B x 48 Panaracer Gravelking (1) 520 g Nordest Albarda 2022
700C x 43 Panaracer Gravelking 410 g not yet used 2023
700C x 55 René Herse Antelope Hill (2) 530 g Marin Gestalt X12B 2023
700C x 48 René Herse Hatcher Pass 475 g Marin Gestalt X12G 2025

(1) My favorite 650B tire and (2) my favorite 700C tire.

With the switch to wide tires came the switch to tubeless. I set up all the above tires tubeless using Orange Seal sealant and a Schwalbe tire booster. I haven't had a flat tire since then. The only disadvantages are the need to add sealant once in a while, the time it takes to clean the rims, and changing rim tapes when changing tires.

Back in 2011, I used Eclipse TPU tubes for my 29er. TPU tubes have made a huge comeback and I'm ready to give them another go. TPU tubes are lighter than butyl and latex tubes and lighter than tubeless sealant. They're also faster, more puncture-resistant, and can easily be patched. Lastly, they pack minimal. TPU tubes are incompatible with CO2 inflators, but I don't use those. René Herse now offers the best of both worlds with a TPU tube sealant — you get the convenience of tubes with the flat-proofness of tubeless. Eclipse does as well!

My recent online purchases around tires:

  • René Herse Antelope Hill tires, 700C x 55 mm, standard tan
  • René Herse Hatcher Pass tires, 700C x 48 mm, standard tan
  • René Herse TPU tubes, 700C x 45-68 mm
  • WTB NanoAir TPU tubes, 700C x 32-47 mm
  • Ridenow TPU tubes, 700C/29" 56G, 45 mm Presta
  • Ridenow TPU tubes, 700C/29" 45G, 45 mm Presta
  • Ridenow TPU tubes, 700C/29" 45G, 65 mm Presta
  • Eclipse TPU sealant

The Hatcher Pass tires will be set up with René Herse TPU tubes and Eclipse TPU sealant. I rode my previous Antelope Hill tires for 5,342.8 km with Orange Seal tubeless milk and never had a flat. Let's see if TPU tubes are as reliable as well.

entry.title: Videos Shot With The DJI Neo
entry.summary: You can't let it rip when riding downhill with a DJI Neo in tow, particularly in the woods. I slow my speed and adjust my lines with the drone in mind. If branches block the Neo's flight path, I slow way down. If I ride around a tree, I slow down and ride around it the farthest possible. It's not a tool to capture the action, but a great tool to capture the scenery.
entry.content:
You can't let it rip when riding downhill with a DJI Neo in tow, particularly in the woods. I slow my speed and adjust my lines with the drone in mind. If branches block the Neo's flight path, I slow way down. If I ride around a tree, I slow down and ride around it the farthest possible. It's not a tool to capture the action, but a great tool to capture the scenery.

The Ittenberg Trail is a nice trail through the woods a few miles from home. It's slightly uphill, so speed isn't high, and the Neo does a marvelous job flying around trees without bumping into them.

On the trail heading east across the Bözingenberg, the DJI Neo has more space to fly, and it's therefore possible to let go of the brakes. As long as I hear the buzz of the little gray hornet, I know it's chasing me.

When riding downhill, you have to ride the trail as if you were a bike guide guiding a beginner down the hill. After all, you can't risk the Neo colliding with a branch on a trail like the Weisse Mauer. If it crashes towards the downhill side of the mountain, you may never find it again.

entry.title: Volagi Viaje 2025 Update
entry.summary: The creme-colored Volagi Viaje SL steel bike saw several updates in 2023 and 2024. The first round of changes was in October 2023, when I switched it from a 2x12 to a 1x12 drivetrain. In March 2024, I swapped derailleurs, and in October, I replaced the Hope calipers. I have a new project in mind for 2025 for which I needed some of the Volagi's components. In doing so, I decided to disassemble my Ritte Snob Disc. I moved the carbon Rotor Aldhu cranks, the spider, the SRAM Red derailleur, the saddle, and the seat post from the Ritte to the Volagi. I also bought a new 4-bolt, 44T Rotor QRing, and a WolfTooth LoneWolf chain guide.
entry.content:
The creme-colored Volagi Viaje SL steel bike saw several updates in 2023 and 2024. The first round of changes was in October 2023, when I switched it from a 2x12 to a 1x12 drivetrain. In March 2024, I swapped derailleurs, and in October, I replaced the Hope calipers. I have a new project in mind for 2025 for which I needed some of the Volagi's components. In doing so, I decided to disassemble my Ritte Snob Disc. I moved the carbon Rotor Aldhu cranks, the spider, the SRAM Red derailleur, the saddle, and the seat post from the Ritte to the Volagi. I also bought a new 4-bolt, 44T Rotor QRing, and a WolfTooth LoneWolf chain guide.

The 4-bolt, 44-tooth, oval Rotor chainring is a work of art. Its CNC-machining is pure perfection. Designed as a dedicated 1x ring, the chain line is moved inward by millimeters. There's ample chainstay clearance, so I love that, as it minimizes the cross-chain effect when riding in the larger cogs, which I use far more than the smallest two cogs.

I replaced the newer Zipp seat post with the older generation post purely for aesthetics. The fork, Thomson handlebar, and Rotor cranks all have a high-gloss finish, and the older, glossy post better matched this. All I have to do now is ride it.

At first, I thought about selling the Ritte Snob Disc frameset and the Industry Nine wheelset, but I'm not ready to part with this bike yet. Instead, I decided to pack it into my travel case. Recently, I saw spy shots of the new SRAM Force road groupset published online. Like the new Red groupset, Force remains a 2x12 configuration. The new Force components would look great on the Ritte, so why not reassemble it in a year or two with those parts?

entry.title: ZTTO 12-Speed 10-44T XDR Cassette
entry.summary: Cassette options have been limited if you’re running a 1x12 XPLR drivetrain on a road or gravel bike. In XDR, SRAM offers the XG-1251 all-steel cassette as well as the XG-1271 with the largest cog in aluminum. There’s also the PG-1231 11-44T for Shimano driver bodies. They never made a Red-level 12-speed cassette to match their Red XPLR derailleur. There’s Garbaruk’s meticulously machined cassette. Eleven of the cogs are CNC-machined out of a solid block of steel. A 44T aluminum sprocket is bolted to that. At 280 grams, it’s the most lightweight gravel cassette. Priced at 280 euros, it costs a euro per gram. It’s a beautiful cassette, and I will certainly get one.
entry.content:
Cassette options have been limited if you’re running a 1x12 XPLR drivetrain on a road or gravel bike. In XDR, SRAM offers the XG-1251 all-steel cassette as well as the XG-1271 with the largest cog in aluminum. There’s also the PG-1231 11-44T for Shimano driver bodies. They never made a Red-level 12-speed cassette to match their Red XPLR derailleur. There’s Garbaruk’s meticulously machined cassette. Eleven of the cogs are CNC-machined out of a solid block of steel. A 44T aluminum sprocket is bolted to that. At 280 grams, it’s the most lightweight gravel cassette. Priced at 280 euros, it costs a euro per gram. It’s a beautiful cassette, and I will certainly get one.

ZTTO now offers a lightweight, affordable alternative. The cassette’s construction is very similar to that from Garbaruk. 11 cogs (10-38T) are machined out of a solid block of high-strength steel. The 44T cog is made from 7075 aluminum and riveted to the two largest steel cogs. Here’s how the different cassettes compare:

SRAM XG-1251 (*) SRAM XDR 10-11-13-15-17-19-21-24-28-32-38-44 425 g + 0 g 127.50 EUR + 0.00 EUR 0.30 EUR/g
SRAM XG-1271 SRAM XDR 10-11-13-15-17-19-21-24-28-32-38-44 378 g - 47 g 177.50 EUR + 50.00 EUR 0.47 EUR/g
ZTTO 10-44T SRAM XDR 10-11-13-15-17-19-21-24-28-32-38-44 342 g - 83 g 99.00 EUR - 28.50 EUR 0.29 EUR/g
Garbaruk 10-44T SRAM XD 10-11-12-14-16-18-21-24-28-32-37-44 280 g - 145 g 280.00 EUR + 152.50 EUR 1.00 EUR/g

ZTTO and SRAM use identical cog sizes. Garbaruk decided to have 1-tooth jumps for the first three gears, and 2-tooth jumps for the next three. Gear 6 through 12 are the same for both cassettes, except for the 11th cog. SRAM has a 38-teeth cog, while Garbaruk went one smaller with 37 teeth. I dislike the jump from 11 to 13 teeth on the SRAM cassette. The chain sitting on the 11T cog often feels too hard of a gear. Shifting up one gear then feels too much of a change. I’m missing that 12T in between. The gear changes on the Garbaruk cassette are possibly smoother. I use the 44T only on steep climbs when I’m too tired to ride out of the saddle. I mostly climb in the 28T and 32T and only use the 38T when it gets steep. Riding in the same fashion should be doable with a 37T.

My ZTTO cassette arrived well-packaged in a small cardboard box. No original packaging or instructions were included, but I don’t mind that, as packaging just creates unnecessary trash. The cassette has a claimed weight of 342 grams, but mine actually weighs only 325 grams. That's only 45 grams more than the Garbaruk cassette at a third of the price. The machining quality and overall finish of the cassette are outstanding. The saying used to be: "Weight, price, strength. Pick two". This no longer seems to apply to products like the ZTTO cassette. You get all three: light, good, and inexpensive.

entry.title: Living Up To The Site's Name
entry.summary: The past two weekends I lived up to the name of this blog. I fat-biked off-trail. On Sunday, January 12th I took my fat-bike to Les Prés d'Orvin for a loop to the Petit Chasseral. The snow conditions were spectacular. The weather however wasn't. It was foggy and a cold wind was blowing. I don't mind that. When I'm out fat-biking on snow, the snow quality is all that matters. The days ahead of the 12th were warm with rainfall. On Friday, the mercury started dropping and went well below zero on the weekend. That gave the snow a nice, hard crust thick enough to carry a cyclist and his fat-bike. This is the absolute best snow a fat-biker can wish for. There’s no need to follow trails of any kind. That's what I love, and that's what I did. The only thing that strong winds and fog don't offer is opportunities to shoot good photos.

The snow conditions were spectacular. The weather however wasn't. It was foggy and a cold wind was blowing. I don't mind that. When I'm out fat-biking on snow, the snow quality is all that matters. The days ahead of the 12th were warm with rainfall. On Friday, the mercury started dropping and went well below zero on the weekend. That gave the snow a nice, hard crust thick enough to carry a cyclist and his fat-bike. This is the absolute best snow a fat-biker can wish for. There’s no need to follow trails of any kind. That's what I love, and that's what I did. The only thing that strong winds and fog don't offer is opportunities to shoot good photos.

The weekend of January 18th and 19th had it all: good snow and a blue sky. I rode for over three hours and 26 km on Saturday, and nearly 4 hours and 28 km on Sunday. Most of the kilometers I rode were off-trail. The wind and weather were perfect for using my DJI Neo. I took it out of my backpack frequently and let it follow me. The video footage isn't something I'd post on YouTube or elsewhere. It's not like I have the skills of a Danny MacAskill or a Brandon Semenuk, and who really wants to watch an old guy ride his fat-bike across the snow? The videos captured dozens of great photos, which I quickly extracted before dinner at home. I uploaded over sixty pictures from those two rides to Flickr.

Until last weekend, I used the DJI Fly app on my iPhone to control the Neo. When the Neo follows me, it’s nice to glance down at the phone to check what the Neo is doing. There’s one major disadvantage, though. Keeping the DJI Fly app running for an extended period drains the battery. So this weekend, I left my iPhone in the pocket of my jacket and used the quick-mode buttons on the Neo. I listened to the sounds and watched for the shadow to ensure it followed. Twice, the Neo couldn’t keep up. When that happens, the drone stops and hovers in place. I turned around and rode toward the Neo. As soon as it recognized me, it flew straight toward me and jumped back into follow mode. In a year or two, I’m definitely getting a faster drone. I’m sure DJI and HOVERAir will compete to produce even more capable self-flying drones. Until then, the Neo is more than good enough.
